resources.string: Learn Java from the beginning. Start with the basics and progress to more advanced topics.
Learn Java from the beginning. Start with the basics and progress to more advanced topics.
Install Java and everything you need. Learn about variables, conditionals, user input and more.

Start with the basics. Preparations for programming. Install Java and everything you need. Learn about variables, conditionals, user input and more. At the end of this chapter, you should be capable of building simple apps.

"

To start learning, you'll first have to install Java. For beginners, an IDE is also recommended. This is what you'll do in this lesson:

1. Download and Install Java

2. Get an IDE (Eclipse)

3. Learn how to create a new Project in Eclipse

In the following sections, you will be guided step by step on how to do these. Tap next to get started!

"

"

We'll start by downloading and installing Java. This tutorial applies for computers running Windows x64. You'll download Java SE Development Kit 8.

1. Go to the Java download webpage
2. Select Accept License Agreement
3. Click on the filename jdk-8u191-windows-x64.exe (click the red down arrow)
4. Run the downloaded executable and follow the onscreen instructions.

Java will now be installed on your computer. After it is done, you are theoretically ready to make Java programs.

However, in the next section, you'll also learn how to download and install an IDE. An Integrated Development Environment is recommended for beginners.

"

"

An Integrated Development Environment (IDE) is a software that makes writing programs easier. You get syntax highlighting, code suggestions, your code is validated as you type and building and running your program is faster and easier. For beginners, these features are very helpful in the learning process.

For Java development we are going to use Eclipse. Eclipse is currently one of the most popular IDEs and possibly the most used one at the time of writing this.

So let's download and install it. Remember, we are downloading the version for Windows x64. Tap next to continue.

"

"

First, go to the Eclipse download page. You can access the download page by typing eclipse.org/downloads in your browser's bar.

Look for the Download button (it's a small orange button). Another page might open and you might have to click the Download button once again. After the setup file has finished downloading, run it.

After a few seconds (it might take longer if your computer is slow) the EclipseInstaller window appears. Choose the Eclipse IDE for Java Developers. Afterwards, you can click the INSTALL button. During installation you might have to click Accept a couple of times.

"

"

Everything is now set! You are ready to start programming in Java. In the next lesson you are going to write your first Java program.

Before doing that, you should know how to use Eclipse. Go ahead and run Eclipse. You will be asked about providing a workspace directory. You can leave that as it is and click the Launch button.

Once the Eclipse IDE opens, go to File > New > Java Project. In the window that opens, you have to write a Project Name (eg.: MyProject) and click Finish button.

Now that you created a Project, you need to create a Class. Click next to continue.

"

"

Every project must contain at least one class. For now, your projects will contain only one class. In this class you will write your program code. This might be confusing for now. That's OK.

To create a class for your project go to File > New > Class. In the window that opens, provide the Name (eg.: MyFirstProgram) and the Source folder which is going to be MyProject/src and leave everything else as it is. Click Finish. You have now created a class in which you can write code.

In the next lesson, we will write a simple Java program. See you there!

"

"

Let's start with the most basic program you can write: the Hello World program. Create a new project with one class named MyFirstApp. Don't know how to do that? Check lesson 1 on how to create a project

You should now be able to write code inside the MyFirstApp class. Write the following code:

public class MyFirstApp {
   public static void main(String[] args) {
      System.out.println( "Hello World!" );
   }
}

In the next sections we will run the program and then explain what every line does.

"

"

In order to run this program just click the green button at the top. Alternatively, you can use the menu at top. Click Run > Run (or press CTRL+F11)

If a dialog appears asking you to save, click OK. The program will now execute. You should see the words "Hello World!" around the bottom area of Eclipse

If there were errors in your code, a dialog will show up, warning you about them. Go back and check that you didn't mispelled anything in your code.

"

"

Let's see what every line of code does:

The first line of code:
public class MyFirstApp

This line declares a class named MyFirstApp and makes it public.

What is a class and a public class? For now, that is not important. All programs in Java run inside a class so we'll have write them like this. You'll learn about what classes are in Chapter III.

"

"

The second line of code was:
public static void main(String[] args)

This line declares a function named main. It also declares this function as public, static, and void. Inside the parentheses, there's the function's parameter String[] args. You'll learn about the meaning of all these in Lesson 8.

However, it's important to understand that every program starts inside this function. The function name is always main and has to be declared exactly like we did above. There can be ONLY ONE main function in every program and it is ALWAYS inside a class. When you execute the program, the code inside the main function will be executed.

If we don't write anything inside, nothing will happen.

"

"

The last line of code that needs explaining is this:
System.out.println( "Hello World!" );

This line will output/print to the screen the words "Hello World!" (without the quote marks ").

We can print anything to screen using the command function:
System.out.println( "Your message here" );

Note the ; at the end.

You can print your own message to screen, or even print more messages by calling the printing function multiple times:
System.out.println( "This is a message" );
System.out.println( "And this is another message" );

Try it! Print your own messages to the screen. Remember that these must be written inside the main function.

"

"

Java is a powerful language and there's more to it than just printing messages on the screen. In the next lesson, you are going to learn a very important concept: variables.

Remember: if there is something unclear, you can always go back and reread any part of any lesson. When your ready, proceed to the next lesson: Variables

"
